item.title: Exit Codes in C# Applications
item.description: When developing console applications in C#, it’s important to communicate the success or failure of your program back to the operating system. This is achieved through exit codes, which are integers returned by the program when it finishes execution. An exit code of 0 typically signifies success, while any non-zero value indicates an error. Setting Exit Codes in C# In C#, you can set the exit code using the Environment.ExitCode property or the Environment.
